If the United States should declare war, Lieutenant Elliott
would recommend all the commissioned officers and sergeants of
the Hopkins Reserve' Officers'
Training Corps of twenty-one
years of age for commissions as
second lieutenants in the Regular
Army or volunteer corps. Moreover, all the members of the corps
who are over eighteen years old
and are physically capable would
probably receive non - commissioned offices in the Army and
would immediately set about
training recruits.
Immediately following a war
declaration, drills of the most
vigorous character would be held
every day. Though at present all
the drill hours are Spent in combat
drill, in learning how to advance
as skirmishers and what to do in
the various stages of attack, these
phases and the many more which
characterize the real battle would
be taught and gone into more minutely. Every afternoon would
find the companies advancing and
rushing in skirmish through the
surrounding woods, solving tactical problems and performing every
act necessary in real combat.
Unfortunately for the battalion, Lieutenant Elliott, who has been
taking his examinations for a
captain's commission during the
last two weeks, would probably
be ordered back to his regiment.
First Sergeant Friedlander would
also probably be ordered back to
his, and First Sergeant Evans
would be put on recruiting duty.
This would leave the battalion in
the hands of Major Linton, who,
however, is able to carry on the
training most efficiently, as he
has had much experience in military work.
One hundred and seventy rifles
have been shipped, for the battalion from Troy, N. Y., and will
arrive as quickly as the railroads
can bring them. They will be
kept in racks which are under
construction in the old gymnasium back of Carroll Mansion. As
most of the drill hours in the last
month have been used in mastering the manual of arms, the battalion is ready to handle the guns
as soon as they appear.

"Resolved, That the trustees of
the Johns Hopkins University
pledge the loyal I support of the
University to the Government of
the United States in its plans for
national defense."
This is the resolution which the
Hopkins Board of Trustees has
sent to President Wilson, as an
indication of the way in which the
University will stand behind him
in case war with Germany is declared.
At the same meeting that this
resolution was adopted, another,
motion was passed which created
a Hopkins Committee on Research
to act in co-operation with the
National Council of Research recently appointed at the President's request by the National
Committee of Science.
The duty of the Hopkins committee will be to stimulate invention in methods of defense
and offense and to assist in the
industrial mobilization of thecountry.
The personnel of the committee
is as follows: The President of
the University, the President of
the Board of Trustees, Ira Remsen, Joseph S. Ames, Walter A.
Baetjer, J. C. W. Frazer, Jacob
H. Hollander,Walter Jones, Burton E. Livingston Harry F. Reid,
William H.Welch, John B.Whitehead, Daniel Willard, Frederick
W. Wood and R. W. Wood.
Just what official steps the University would take in case war is
declared can not of course be predicted.. There seems to be little
doubt in official quarters how'could
ever, that the Government
call upon the University to do•
anything within its power, at
whatever sacrifice the act would
be performed.

graduated a few months earlier,

Goodnow said that such a matter
would have to be determined by
the faculty. His manner indicated, however, that the loyalty
of Hopkins students would not
necessitate the sacrifice or postponement of their degrees.

The list, when it has been compiled, will immediately be sent to
the United States War Department. If war is declared it will
give the Government valuable aid
in providing it with access to the
services of thousands of highly
trained men.
At the present time it seems
probable that there will be more
need of physicists and chemists
than of the men who have pursued
other branches of learning. The
list, however, is to be comprehensive.

Active plans are being carried
out at the Johns Hopkins Hospital for the formation of a base
hospital that would be placed at
the disposal of the Government in
the event of war. The Government is encouraging the organization of such hospital units in all
the large medical schools and hospitals in the country. About
thirty of these have been formed,
of which Hopkins is listed as unit
No. 18.
The personnel of the staff in the
proposed unit and the equipment
being gathered at Hopkins are of
such a character as to mark Hopkins as one of the best base hospitals at the Government's disposal.
Dr. Winford Smith is the director
of the organization and he has under him some of the most prominentphysicians and surgeons in the
city. The staff is made up of doctors who are or have been connected with Hopkins.
In addition to the doctors on
the staff, there is a large reserve
list of those who desire to offer
their services in time of war,
which will make it possible for
the Hopkins unit to increase its
staff in a great emergency, and to
keep its ranks always full of competent physicians.
The staff is divided into three
groups: The surgeons, the physicians and the laboratory workers.
Dr. J. M. T. Finney is the chief
of the surgical division and he has

and Dr. Boggs of the laboratory

work, an adjutant, a quartermaster, a registrar, a chaplain and a
staff of about eighty orderlies,

Outdoor track practice at
Homewood Field started on Monday, March 12. The team was the
first out on the field for the season, and an extremely enthusiastic spirit was shown.
Coach England attaches particular significance to the warm
reception accorded the Johns Hopkins representative, Capt. Harry
Straus, at the convention of the
I. C. A. A. A. A. at Philadephia
a fortnight ago. Johns Hopkins
was placed in a position of particular prominence by the splendid sendoff given us by Mr. Kirby, chairman of the executive committee. Coach England considers
this a direct indication of the
high place Johns Hopkins is rapidly taking in track athletics. It
is hoped that an I. C. A. A. A. A.
meet to be held annually at
Homewood Field can be arranged
in the near future.

At the tryouts held last Thursday, the following men were
chosen to represent the University
in the annual triangular debate
between North Carolina, Virginia
and Hopkins:
Affirmative Team—Eugene A.
Edgett, '17; Alexander A. Steinbach, '17, chairman; Henry C.
Evans, '18, alternate.
Negative Team — Morton K.
Rothschild, '18; Reuben Oppen'17, chairman; Robert R. Duncan,
'18, alternate.
• The number of the participants
in the tryouts was unusually large,
and Dr. French expressed himself as exceptionally well pleased
both by the increased interest in
debate shown and by the calibre
of the speeches themselves.
The debate between the three
universities will be held on the
night of April 28. The subject,
the same as that of the Hopkins
interclass debate, is: "Resolved,
-That, constitutionality waived,
legislation providing for the compulsory arbitration of all labor
disputes in interstate railways
and prohibiting all strikes and
lockouts in such railways should
be enacted."
The Hopkins affirmative team
will meet Virginia at the University of North Carolina while the
negative will debate North Carolina at the University of Virginia:
Virginia and North Carolina will
meet in the assembly hall of the
J. H. U. Civil Engineering Building. The three debates will take
place simultaneously.
All of the men chosen to debate for Hopkins were in the interclass debate held on the night
The sides in that
of March 3. '

same side in the intercollegiates

Owing to the fact that the
course in international law was
not given this year at the University, a series of lectures has been
arranged on problems of international law of present interest.
These will start about Easter and
will continue through April and
May.
Mr. Emory Hamilton Niles
(Johns Hopkins, '13), who was a
Rhodes scholar and who has re•cently returned from Oxford, will
give the lectures. The course will
be open to undergraduates and
will include discussions of the
international laws relating to
armed merchant ships, contraband, blockades, use of neutral
flags and such subjects of general
interest. The course will be given
those interested in the subject,
but no credit will be allowed and
no examination given. •
While at Oxford, Mr. Niles distinguished himself by carrying off
highest honors. He won double
first-class honors by getting first
class in jurisprudence and also in
the examination for bachelor of
civil law. While at Hopkins,
Niles, in addition to winning
scholastic honors, was one of the
mainstays of the lacrosse team
and was an editor of THE NEwsTAETTER.
Elsewhere in this issue will be
found an account by Mr. Niles of
conditions in English universities
during the war.

Work upon the first Homewood
dormitory will be begun some
time during next winter, and the
building will be in full operation
a year from next fall, was the
statement made by Dean Brush
to a representative of TIIE NEWSLETTER last week.
Although it had first been
planned to have the dormitory
erected by the opening of the University after the coming vacation,
delay in the completion of the
architectural arrangements and
the heavy expense necessitated by
the removal to Homewood have
made it advisable to postpone the
erection of the building for one
year. It is highly improbable,
however, that any further postponement will occur.
The dormitory is to be built to
the right of Gilman Hall, facing
the boulevard.- Ultimately there
will be a group of three or four
dormitories, and the site of the
contemplated building is being
carefully chosen, so that it will
harmonize in the general scheme.
The colonial style will of course
be preserved—a style which is peculiarly well adapted to the laying out of living accommodations.
The building is to be in the form
of a hollow rectangle, with one
of the sides omitted. When the
second dormitory is built, it will
be placed opposite the first, so
that, between them, a quadrangle
will be formed.
The dining hall will be on the
first floor, while the bedrooms and
studies for the most part, will
be on time second. It was at first
planned by the architects to have
the studies face upon the court;
but, as the plans now stand, the
studies will face outward. The
colonial features of the dormitory
are to be strictly confined to the
appearance—in the matter of comfort and convenience, the building will be as up to date as the
most modern structure of its kind
in the country.
The Homewood dormitories,
when all of them have been built,
will carry out the English idea
rather than the American one.
The students are not to be crowded into one or two large buildings; instead, there will be a number of smaller ones, ik each of
\Odell the group life will have a
far better opportunity of development.
The charges for accommodation
in the dormitory are to be placed
as low as the actual cost of operation will permit. The Dormitory
Committee has for its aim the development of a university life
rather thnn the furnishing of a
source of revenue. It will only
be required that the dormitory be
self-supporting.

The committee appointed by the
Omicron Delta Kappa Circle to
arouse interest in Hopkins among
the preparatory schools of Maryland and the neighboring cities
carried its work over the State
border into Washington, D. C., on
March 9, when Hopkins students
spoke at three high schools in one
day.
At 9 o'clock in the morning the
speakers told of the advantages
of Hopkins to the upper classes
of McKinley Manual Training
School.
The first speaker, Mitchell B.
Carroll, told briefly of the salient
features of the curriculum and
the inducements which the Hopkins undergraduate academic and
engineering departments have to
offer. William Swartz next described vividly, with the aid of
slides, the buildings and other attractive features of the campus;
and Fred Hall, the chairman of
the committee, closed the program
with an interesting illustrated
talk on Hopkins' activities.
At 1.30 o'clock the trio addressed the upper classes of Western High School. Although about
two-thirds of the audience were
girls, the speakers seemed to create an interest in Hopkins and
their efforts were rewarded by
several men signifying their intention of attending the University.
From Western the team of
speakers rushed to the St. Albans
School for Boys.
On last Friday another team
spoke at Hagerstown High School
in the afternoon and at St. James'
High School in the evening. The
speeches were given in the same
order as before, with John Mowbray as first speaker, Allan K.
Chalmers as second and Frederick
Hall last.

"There is, a sharp line of demarcation between imperialism
and dentocracy," declared David
Jayne Hill, LL. D.,. the James
Schouler lecturer for 1917, in the
third of a series of lectures on
"International Readjustments," in
the Civil Engineering Building on
Tuesday, March 13.
Dr. Hill went on to say that
imperial aggressions were always
served to the people as a sort of
sugared pill; that they Were disguised under the repulsion of pretended aggression, as the realization of national aspirations or as
the righting of wrongs done to
small nations; and that niertenary gains were represented as
merely attendants of this "lofty
purpose."
"And, indeed," he continued,
"every existing European • state
was created by military power.
So long as the theory. of imperialism is held, war will continue.
The future of the civilized world
depends upon .whether the state
is to be a creation of force or of
.law. If the former, then it is
right to prepare. Only the strong
will survive, and nations must_
fight for their existence."
Dr. Hill said America should
support the 'entente allies' ideal,
declaring they have appealed to
the, conscience of mankind in recognizing that imperialism is not
merely a sort of harmless national
pride, but a real spirit and creed.
In sUpport of this statement, he
read excerpts from several inflammatory pamphlets spread
through Central Europe by the
pan-Germanists before the war. •
Long before the outbreak of the
present war and even as.far back
as 1885, the more radical element
in Germany were apparently lusting for world dominion, Dr. Hill
said. He cited the predictions of
a German writer of that date who
had constructed maps of a worldwide Teutonic empire and. told
how it could be acquired. Among
other things, France was to cede
large portions of her eastern front
and to pay a huge indeninity. The
seizure of Cuba and the Philippines was also part of the plan.
Cuba seemed an ideal point from
which to dominate the Gulf of
Mexico and to establish a closer
connection with the ten million
Germans in America.
"And, although I do not assert
that these ideals were held by the
rulers of Germany," Dr Hill con. eluded, "it is nevertheless a sign i hcant fact that 90 percent. of it
has been, at least temporarily,
carried out since 1914."

The works of Dr. Edward Meyer,
of Berlin, and of Dr. Nauman
were discussed in order to bring
out the ideals and aims of the
German Empire of today.
By quoting Dr. Meyer, Dr. Hill
showed that the Germans believe
that the earth can not have peace
until Germany is victorious.
Meyer says that if Germany were
defeated, it would mean continuous war in the future until ,Germany has secured what she wants.
She is thinking of her own interests, regardless of international
law.
Still quoting from Meyer, Dr.
Hill said that in order to succeed in her plans of expansion
and aggression, Germany was
striving to perfect her military
organization, perfect her marine
organization, so as to make her
independent of the rest of the
world, and to establish her emperor as an absolute monarch.
The Germans believe that this war
is a fight to the finish between hnperialism and democracy ; that
imperialism, as exemplified by
Germany, will conquer and that
democracy will be expelled from
the earth.
"The new Germany," Dr. Hill
said," will be prepared for war,
will be under one absolute ruler,
accountable to no one,whose interest will be the extension of his
power. Peace can only come when
it is imposed by the conqueror.

This is the claim and the boast-of Germany."
Dr. Hill then called up a vision
of Germany as she used to be—
Germany, the teacher of science,
of art, of niusic, of literature.
The new Germany, he said, desires a union with Austria that
will cement the two into one powerful nation, fortified from the
test of the world. The sthall
states, according to Germany's
idea, would soon be frightened
into adherance to the Central
Powers, as that would be their
only means of. securing protection
and peace.
"In all the German ideals," he
continued, "there is no proposal
to restore peace, and no reference
to neutrals, except to say that
small states can not remain aloof,
but must seek entrance into the
Central Powers. In expressing
this idea in one of his books, Dr.
Nauman significantly remarks
that all treaties with small states
may not be respected."
"According to German writers,"
the lecturer added sarcastically,
"these ideals and aims for German dominion of most of Europe,
•if not of the world,•did not antedate the war, and did not enter
into the causes of the war."

"Internat ional Organization."

SENIOR BANQUET THIS THURSDAY

TRYOUTS TO BE HELD MARCH 26

President Goodnow, Dean Brush, and
Professor Thomas to Be Guests of
Honor --Junior Celebration to
Be Held on March 29.

Hopkins Representative Will Compete
With Orators From Other State Colleges in Discussion of Proposed
League to Enforce Peace.

Arrangements for three of the
annual class banquets are rapidly
being completed'. The Senior banquet will be held at the Rennert
Hotel on March 22. A committee consisting of Allan Davis
(chairman), Randolph Smith,
Robert Merrick and Bertram Winchester has been appointed. Dr.
Goodnow, Dean Brush and Professor Thomas, honorary president of the class, have been asked
to speak, and Edward Stuart will
probably be selected as toastmaster.
Among the members of the class
who will probably speak are
Frederick Hall, Paul Sutton and
Trueman Thompson. A number
of interesting innovations and
surprises are being worked out.
The Junior banquet is to take
place at the Emerson Hotel on
March 29. It will be called the
"Philosophers' Banquet," Dr. Slonimsky being the principal speaker. A committee consisting of
Stuart Egerton (chairman), Robert Hoffman, Henry Evans and
Wilmot Jacobsen has been chosen
to have charge of arrangements.
The Sophomore banquet will be
held the week following the Junior banquet. A committee consisting of Ronald Cox(chairman),
D. W. Burbage, Gordon Gatchell,
R. C. Cox, Herbert Baxley, G. F.
Ordeman, A. Hamburger and H.
L. Prince was chosen at the class
meeting on Thursday to have
charge of arrangements.

The annual State contest of the
Intercollegiate Peace Association
will be held on Friday, April 20,
in the Civil Engineering Building. The preliminary contest to •
select a representative for Johns
Hopkins will take place in the
same building on Monday, March
26, at 1 o'clock.
For the local contest the oration
may be as brief as five minutes.
It must be on some aspect of the
proposed league to enforce peace.
According to the rules of the Association at least three contestants must appear to make the
choice legal.
The winner of the preliminary
contest will represent Johns Hopkins in the State contest. If successful there, he will deliver the
same oration in a group contest
of the South Atlantic States. The
winner of that contest meets the
representatives of other groups of
States in a final contest at Lake
Mohonk. In this final contest,
each orator receives a prize, the
winner receiving $100. In 1916,
Mr. Francis Case, of Dakota Wesleyan University, won first place
in the Lake Mohonk contest.
All these contests are held under the rules of the Intercollegiate Peace Association, a nationwide organization whose chief
function is to further the cause
of international arbitration by
creating interest in it among college men.

Work upon the first Homewood
dormitory will be begun some
time during next winter, and the
building will be in full operation
a year from next fall, was the
statement made by Dean Brush
to a representative of TIIE NEWSLETTER last week.
Although it had first been
planned to have the dormitory
erected by the opening of the University after the coming vacation,
delay in the completion of the
architectural arrangements and
the heavy expense necessitated by
the removal to Homewood have
made it advisable to postpone the
erection of the building for one
year. It is highly improbable,
however, that any further postponement will occur.
The dormitory is to be built to
the right of Gilman Hall, facing
the boulevard.- Ultimately there
will be a group of three or four
dormitories, and the site of the
contemplated building is being
carefully chosen, so that it will
harmonize in the general scheme.
The colonial style will of course
be preserved—a style which is peculiarly well adapted to the laying out of living accommodations.
The building is to be in the form
of a hollow rectangle, with one
of the sides omitted. When the
second dormitory is built, it will
be placed opposite the first, so
that, between them, a quadrangle
will be formed.
The dining hall will be on the
first floor, while the bedrooms and
studies for the most part, will
be on time second. It was at first
planned by the architects to have
the studies face upon the court;
but, as the plans now stand, the
studies will face outward. The
colonial features of the dormitory
are to be strictly confined to the
appearance—in the matter of comfort and convenience, the building will be as up to date as the
most modern structure of its kind
in the country.
The Homewood dormitories,
when all of them have been built,
will carry out the English idea
rather than the American one.

Omicron Committee Has Many High
School Students Signify Intention of Entering Hopkins—Sends Speakers to
Washington and Hagerstown.

Dr. Hill, Schouler Lecturer,Says That,in
Fighting Against Imperialism, Allies
Are Appealing to the Conscience of Mankind.

The committee appointed by the
Omicron Delta Kappa Circle to
arouse interest in Hopkins among
the preparatory schools of Maryland and the neighboring cities
carried its work over the State
border into Washington, D. C., on
March 9, when Hopkins students
spoke at three high schools in one
day.
At 9 o'clock in the morning the
speakers told of the advantages
of Hopkins to the upper classes
of McKinley Manual Training
School.
The first speaker, Mitchell B.
Carroll, told briefly of the salient
features of the curriculum and
the inducements which the Hopkins undergraduate academic and
engineering departments have to
offer. William Swartz next described vividly, with the aid of
slides, the buildings and other attractive features of the campus;
and Fred Hall, the chairman of
the committee, closed the program
with an interesting illustrated
talk on Hopkins' activities.
At 1.30 o'clock the trio addressed the upper classes of Western High School. Although about
two-thirds of the audience were
girls, the speakers seemed to create an interest in Hopkins and
their efforts were rewarded by
several men signifying their intention of attending the University.
From Western the team of
speakers rushed to the St. Albans
School for Boys.

"There is, a sharp line of demarcation between imperialism
and dentocracy," declared David
Jayne Hill, LL. D.,. the James
Schouler lecturer for 1917, in the
third of a series of lectures on
"International Readjustments," in
the Civil Engineering Building on
Tuesday, March 13.
Dr. Hill went on to say that
imperial aggressions were always
served to the people as a sort of
sugared pill; that they Were disguised under the repulsion of pretended aggression, as the realization of national aspirations or as
the righting of wrongs done to
small nations; and that niertenary gains were represented as
merely attendants of this "lofty
purpose."
"And, indeed," he continued,
"every existing European • state
was created by military power.
So long as the theory. of imperialism is held, war will continue.
The future of the civilized world
depends upon .whether the state
is to be a creation of force or of
.law. If the former, then it is
right to prepare. Only the strong
will survive, and nations must_
fight for their existence."
Dr. Hill said America should
support the 'entente allies' ideal,
declaring they have appealed to
the, conscience of mankind in recognizing that imperialism is not
merely a sort of harmless national
pride, but a real spirit and creed.
In sUpport of this statement, he
read excerpts from several inflammatory pamphlets spread
through Central Europe by the
pan-Germanists before the war. •
Long before the outbreak of the
present war and even as.far back
as 1885, the more radical element
in Germany were apparently lusting for world dominion, Dr. Hill
said. He cited the predictions of
a German writer of that date who
had constructed maps of a worldwide Teutonic empire and. told
how it could be acquired. Among
other things, France was to cede
large portions of her eastern front
and to pay a huge indeninity. The
seizure of Cuba and the Philippines was also part of the plan.
Cuba seemed an ideal point from
which to dominate the Gulf of
Mexico and to establish a closer
connection with the ten million
Germans in America.
"And, although I do not assert
that these ideals were held by the
rulers of Germany," Dr Hill con. eluded, "it is nevertheless a sign i hcant fact that 90 percent. of it
has been, at least temporarily,
carried out since 1914."

of Berlin, and of Dr. Nauman

German Empire of today.
By quoting Dr. Meyer, Dr. Hill
showed that the Germans believe
that the earth can not have peace
until Germany is victorious.
Meyer says that if Germany were
defeated, it would mean continuous war in the future until ,Germany has secured what she wants.
She is thinking of her own interests, regardless of international
law.
Still quoting from Meyer, Dr.
Hill said that in order to succeed in her plans of expansion
and aggression, Germany was
striving to perfect her military
organization, perfect her marine
organization, so as to make her
independent of the rest of the
world, and to establish her emperor as an absolute monarch.
The Germans believe that this war
is a fight to the finish between hnperialism and democracy ; that
imperialism, as exemplified by
Germany, will conquer and that
democracy will be expelled from

"The new Germany," Dr. Hill
said," will be prepared for war,
will be under one absolute ruler,
accountable to no one,whose interest will be the extension of his
power. Peace can only come when
it is imposed by the conqueror.

This is the claim and the boast-of Germany."
Dr. Hill then called up a vision
of Germany as she used to be—
Germany, the teacher of science,
of art, of niusic, of literature.
The new Germany, he said, desires a union with Austria that

test of the world. The sthall
states, according to Germany's
idea, would soon be frightened

Powers, as that would be their
only means of. securing protection
and peace.

continued, "there is no proposal

small states can not remain aloof,
but must seek entrance into the
Central Powers. In expressing
this idea in one of his books, Dr.
Nauman significantly remarks
that all treaties with small states
may not be respected."
"According to German writers,"
the lecturer added sarcastically,
"these ideals and aims for German dominion of most of Europe,
•if not of the world,•did not antedate the war, and did not enter
into the causes of the war."

Mohonk. In this final contest,

winner receiving $100. In 1916,

function is to further the cause
of international arbitration by
creating interest in it among college men.
